29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britai. Coming up Andy
is with a fledgling crow shooting pigeons

36.text: sushi-style on what will be wasabi peas.

41.text:
We are hand lining out of the back of a sea
boat on the south coast of England and catching

45.text:
First, it's the silly season where stalkers
all over Europe get roebuck fever. We are

51.text:
out with Roy Lupton on four separate outings
to learn as much as we can about how to call

58.text:
Even if we do say so ourselves we have filmed
some lovely reactions to the call it has become

65.text:
a bit of a tradition around about the end
of July beginning of August when every roe

69.text:
buck in Europe starts to behave like a John
Travolta in Grease. This year Roy wants to

80.text:
film the roe rut from top to bottom and end
to end. He wants to try and surpass everything

85.text:
we have done before and decides to head out
on four different occasions during the rut

89.text:
to cover as much ground as possible. We are
not looking to shoot everything in sight of

94.text:
course he wants to take a few animals, but
it is all about working the call, watching

98.text:
So the rut has kicked off. I have spoken to
a few friends and they say that the roe are

102.text:
really responding well to the call. It has
been really stormy and the storm has been

108.text:
building and unfortunately now it has just
broken and it is absolutely tipping down.

111.text:
Our first outing is not ideal. Pouring rain
the first proper showers for weeks. But it

117.text:
is a good test rain is never thought as a
good thing for a stalker. So will it affect

122.text:
the bucks looking for love at this time of
the year.

125.text:
This evening we are joined by Mr Crow, who
has come along for the ride and who looks

128.text:
very dapper in Roy's head gear. He doesn't
use a call so is interested to see it in action.

134.text:
Roy picks a spot and the call falls on deaf
ears. We give it ten minutes and move on.

140.text:
We are now getting soaked. Roy calls again,
nothing so we start setting up the fox call,

147.text:
but then out from the scrub comes a buck.
He stops on the call but he has spotted us.

152.text:
Lesson number one, it pays to be patient even
when it is raining and of course there is

158.text:
Perhaps if we had continued and persevered
a little bit more we would have had a little

161.text:
bit more of a successful outcome. I am blaming
that one Andy though. I am sure he has jinxed

165.text: Why are you blaming me Roy.

166.text: I can't believe you did that.

167.text:
Why are you blaming me I did say to you squeak
a bit longer.

172.text: I must have misheard that bit.

174.text:
I said to you squeak a bit longer, you never
know whether you arouse something.

182.text: It does, it does me anyway.

185.text:
We try calling a fox but nothing so to finish
off we decide to give Jordan a heart attack.

190.text:
We have got an elephant call on this. So we
are going to play just as he tries to grab

199.text: That is not fair he didn't even jump.

204.text:
Jordan too cool for school there. We soon
give up just like the camera and wait for

209.text:
better weather. Five days later we are in
Hampshire and it is going to be speed stalking.

215.text:
Day two, or day two filming on the doe buck
rut. We have got a couple thousand acres to

219.text:
get round quickly as we can so we are going
to go to likely looking spots where hopefully

224.text:
there might be some roe couched up and just
see if we can get some behaviour happening

229.text:
Our first field sighting is a doe grazing
near the browse line Roy spotted earlier.

234.text:
She doesn't clock us in the crop, undisturbed
she disappears back into the wood, but only

238.text:
to reappear with this chap behind her. It
is the big buck Roy has been leaving alone.

243.text:
So that is the big boy. He has got his nose
right up her behind so the chances of him

250.text: calling off of her are quite slim.

254.text:
We venture into the woods and try a few more
tricks to stir up a response. Roy finds the

259.text:
inner gorilla shaking foliage and even the
inner raging bull with a bit of ground pawing.

267.text:
The local bucks are clearly intimidated and
don't break cover, but our luck is about to

272.text:
change. A buck is feeding a couple of hundred
yards away beyond the maize.

276.text:
If we call from here and he does respond we
are just going to disappear into the maize

278.text:
and the chances are he will see us before
we see him. So we are going to go around that

282.text:
way and creep up on him. Going to give him
a call. It doesn't look like he is with a

288.text:
doe. But hopefully we might be able to get
him to play.

337.text:
What a reaction and just what we had hoped
for.

339.text:
That couldn't have worked out any better.
He came beautifully in then. With a few squeaks

341.text:
you could see that he wasn't on a doe the
way he wasn't following. Perfect response

351.text:
and he came right in. That is a very nice
representative six pointer. So very happy

360.text:
with that one. I would have preferred actually
to have taken something a bit younger. Not

368.text:
quite as nice. He hasn't got that strong a
head but he is a very nice representative

373.text:
buck. You can tell by his neck, he has got
a good thick neck on him. Nice shoulders on

379.text:
him so he certainly wasn't a young animal,
but a good middle aged buck. He is beautiful

396.text:
With buck gralloched in the back of the truck
we are off calling again. This time it is

401.text:
With any luck there might be a buck around
here. It will be quite interesting with the

410.text:
doe just standing there so we can see her
before we start calling and just see what

428.text:
She heads into the cover and then reappears
a minute later. With the butalo call clearly

442.text:
working we ask Roy to run through his technique.
When we are calling I always follow the instructions

448.text:
from a guy that used to take me out when I
was a lot younger roe stalking, John Tobin.

453.text:
He has taught me that when you are using the
call it should be like a heart beat so just

459.text:
a regular rhythmic heart beat to start off
with. So just a ... just stop for a little

467.text:
while and watch, give it a couple of minutes
and go again and just run through the calls

475.text:
like that. Obviously that heart rate is one
that we haven't seen the buck. When you tend

480.text:
to see a deer coming in all of a sudden it
increases. That call will very often bring

486.text:
does in. The reason for that is because it
is mimicking the sound of the roe kids. So

492.text:
if they have lost their mum then they are
just calling out and if there is a buck with

497.text:
them, very often the buck will come in as
well. You can then up the anti and start increasing

503.text:
the intensity of the call as if it is a
doe being chased by a buck. That will often

507.text:
bring the territorial buck out because he
thinks that somebody else is playing with

512.text:
his girl friend and on his territory. When
you get to the end which is a little bit of

519.text:
a distress call as if a deer is being hounded
a little bit more. Very often that will spark

525.text:
if you haven't had anything. If they have
been rutting hard and their and they are couched

529.text:
up. If there is a buck laying around that
sometimes will bring them in or just spark

532.text:
them a little bit when there is nothing going
on.

536.text:
Our next success is again with a doe feeding
near a wood which is supposed to be our next

540.text:
stop. Roy gets her attention. She spots us
and charges into the wood barking. Not ideal.

550.text:
Our last call of the day is another long distance
response. A doe comes hurtling up the side

555.text:
of the crops. Stopping within 12 yards of
Roy. Running roe deer, crouching Lupton.

559.text:
Every year it just takes my breath away and
I think that just keeps driving us to do what

571.text:
we do because it is not just about the hunting
it is about the appreciation of wildlife,

574.text:
the appreciation of the countryside and the
appreciation of understanding exactly what

580.text:
is going on and admiring the quarry. Every
time you get one coming in it sends tingles

585.text:
down your spine, the hairs standing up on
the back of the neck. It is just beautiful.

590.text:
Roe stalking take three. We are back to where
we started. It is not raining it is scorching

595.text:
which may mean it is too hot for the roe to
be feeling amorous and the rut might become

599.text: nocturnal. Roy is also feeling the heat.

603.text:
I am very sure I resemble a stuffed sausage
on a barbecue at the moment. But the plan

616.text:
at the moment is I want to spot the buck before
we try and call him. Because in this maize

618.text:
if we try and call him it could very easily
come round us and get our wind without us

625.text:
even knowing and disappear. So we are just
going to wait it out before we start making

629.text:
any noise and hopefully we will spot them.
As it is cooling down I am hoping they are

631.text:
going to come out into the open parts, open
margins and start feeding.

635.text:
An hour and half passes and the light is dropping
fast. Finally Roy spots the buck with the

640.text:
doe and we need to work our way in. It means
a crawl. Roy can't get a clean shot because

646.text:
of the long grass. We manoeuvre and eventually
the buck turns broad side. It runs but drops

657.text:
I was just waiting for him to turn broadside
before I could squeeze a shot and he eventually

662.text:
gave us the opportunity, but as you can see
that is one hot, hot evening.

667.text:
Roy is happy, but clearly a hot man. So buck
number two, but not the spectacle we have

673.text:
come to expect. Our last excursion brings
with it a guest appearance, roe calling guru

679.text:
John Tobin, taught Roy everything he knows.
We haven't filmed John for four years. He

684.text:
appeared in one of our first ever films bringing
you responses like this. Tonight he is behind

700.text:
the call again. It is our last hoorah and
it is not going well. In fact we see nothing.

707.text:
Has the rut stopped. Probably not as this
is the result our friend Keith had on the

712.text:
same ground. A disappointing end, but Roy
can at least ask John a few questions about

717.text: our experiences over the last few days.

719.text:
One of the things I always struggle with is
if you have got a buck with a doe and are

724.text:
trying to get either the doe to come or the
buck to move in or leave the doe, what would

731.text:
We all learnt in night clubs that a certainty
is better than a maybe and that is what you

736.text:
are trying to do. I tend to use a distress
call as that usually gets some form of reaction.

744.text: Can you give us a quick spin on that.

747.text:
Well we can give it a go. It is ... something
like that. And just be persistent you almost

760.text:
And do you pay much attention to wind in the
rut.

763.text:
No I don't pay any attention to it at all.
I don't think it makes any difference at all.

770.text: You can take liberties with the wind.

773.text:
So we end with some of Tobin's top tips. To
hear more from John click on the link of our

778.text:
film with him in 2009. It has been a fascinating
few days and I hope the roe have been giving

783.text:
you wonderful wildlife moments over the past
weeks too.

789.text:
Roy showing there that you can never second
guess wildlife which makes it so exhilarating.

794.text:
And if you want to know more about any of
the kit that Roy uses from Webley air rifles

799.text:
to ... torches, please contact him on Facebook.
But be patient he is a busy boy. Now to another

806.text:
buck who comes into the call. It is David
on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

821.text:
George Digweed has won his 22nd world championship.
The ueber-shooter won the World English Sporting

828.text:
Championships in Canada by just two clays.
That brings his tally to two worlds and two

835.text:
Singer PJ Harvey has had antis slagging her
off because she supports foxhunting. In an

842.text:
interview in NME magazine, the British pop
sensation said "Seeing the hunt out on the

847.text: fields is just so natural to me."

851.text:
With the Glorious Twelfth and the start of
grouse-shooting season just round the corner,

855.text:
it's the turn of a Scottish agent to give
his views on the upcoming season. Last week,

861.text:
Robert Benson of the Moorland Association
predicted a late season as many broods were

866.text:
late this year. Now here's Lachie Smith from
Highland Sporting with his view.

870.text:
Pretty much of what I've heard of so far they
seem quite happy with what they have got number-wise,

875.text:
but they are all sizes. Towards the end of
August, they will be better then, is my view,

881.text: but - you know - that is only me.

884.text:
And finally, an angler fishing off the coast
of Nantucket had a dose of fishing rage when

889.text:
a shark pinched his catch. Elliot Sudal jumped
into the water, grabbed the shark and hauled

895.text:
it out along with the remains of his bluefish.
He later claims he has done that to hundreds

901.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories - fishing for facts.

911.text:
Thank you David - Now after Crow finally dried
off he invited us out pigeon shooting on a

919.text: standing crop of peas. It's CrowHow.

935.text:
It's difficult to age The Crowman and I wouldn't
ask. It would be like asking Joan Collins

940.text:
if she dyed her hair. But there are a few
signs that suggest he's starting to feel the

947.text:
The giveaways are: a young jedi is doing a
lot of the graft today, he's got some new

952.text:
hearing aids and lastly he's blagged a hide
tray from GMS to save his back from all that

959.text:
bending down for the Clear Pigeons, his lunch
and his squash.

963.text:
Anyway, let's not dwell - Today Andy is going
to show us what's needed to shoot over a standing

968.text:
crop. Lots of people don't like it but if
it has to be done this is how to do it.

974.text:
I don't like shooting in standing crops. It
is one thing I don't like doing because you

978.text:
can't pick them. In this particular field
there is a thin bit out the front. It is probably

983.text:
40, probably 50 yards long, about 50 yards
wide. It is probably bigger than that 60 yards

989.text:
long, 50 yards wide. You can just see it there
are a few peas there but not many. If you

994.text:
get out there it is open and as you can see
right along the headland here I probably shoot

998.text:
80% of my birds. I let them go past and drop
them on the headland where there isn't anything.

1004.text:
The last thing I want to do is shoot them
and not pick them up, because that is one

1007.text:
thing that does wind me up, people shooting
pigeons and not picking them. Because to me

1012.text:
they are a game bird, they are vermin, but
to me they are a game bird. I would sooner

1016.text: shoot them than anything else really.

1017.text:
So Andy roughly knows where they're going
to drop, where the dog will make simple retrieves

1022.text:
and where she might need some guidance. Marking
where a bird drops is also important. If you

1028.text:
can't do it mentally - write it down just
like they do in the grouse butts.

1032.text:
Standing crops also requires specialised decoying
equipment - literally to raise your game.

1038.text:
There's no point having decoys hidden away.
Crow uses some homemade cradles and others

1044.text:
You want to be getting the pigeons up off
the ground a bit. I have got two different

1049.text:
cradles here that you can get from A1. This
one has got a spring so you can put a big

1055.text:
stick in it, you can have it what ever height
you want as you can see from the ones I have

1060.text:
put over there. I put them up higher than
the crop. The ones I have got are painted

1063.text:
with white so when you do put them down you
can still see them. I have got one over there

1066.text:
which is on a stick but hasn't got a pigeon
in it you can see even from here ten, fifteen

1070.text:
yards you can still see it, but if it was
a green one you wouldn't have any chance to

1076.text:
see it. So my advice is to paint them white
might seem silly but the thing is the pigeons

1082.text:
are sitting on top of it by the time the pigeons
have seen it is underneath it is dead anyway

1089.text:
We're almost good to go. All we need now are
the finishing touches. Keen shooter William

1094.text:
puts together the new Lincoln deluxe for Crow
and assembles the hide tray - child's play

1099.text:
- all that's missing is the stair lift, the
commode and we'd be in OAP heaven.

1105.text:
Come on Crow - you've got visitors. I said:
you've got visitors. let's knock some pigeons

1121.text:
Andy is often asked about the chokes he uses
- With his usual single barrelled semi-auto

1135.text:
he tend to shift between half and quarter
choke depending on the day but with the double

1140.text:
barrelled Lincoln he can have the best of
both worlds- one for close stuff the other

1145.text:
The gun has got a single selective trigger
so you can use the top barrel or the bottom

1151.text:
barrel which ever.I tend to have the open
choke in the top barrel so if I only have

1157.text:
one shot I can eject and it is just as easy
to stick a cartridge into the top barrel than

1160.text:
fumble about and try and get it into the bottom
barrel. If the pigeons are coming a bit quick

1164.text:
you can eject them out and it is easier just
to stick one into the top barrel.

1170.text:
It really is a stinking hot day and Crow is
also keen to remind people that fluids are

1174.text:
not only essential for the guns but the dogs
too. Ruby is panting hard.

1178.text:
I brought the dog today because we have got
a few stands, well some of its stands and

1182.text:
I will get a few runners. At least I can get
the dog to go through it and make sure you

1186.text:
bring a load of water. The dog has got more
water than me as it goes. We always make sure

1194.text:
we take a load of water for the dog. You know
what it is like yourself. Look after the dog.

1197.text:
Crow is a little disappointed. Last year he
had a bumper day on this field and only 48

1202.text:
hours earlier when he and Will recce'd here
the birds were landing at their feet. Nevertheless

1207.text:
Crow is making contact with anything having
a look. And those that do fall away from the

1212.text:
thin areas of crop Ruby works her magic - only
once does Crow think a bird is too far for

1217.text: her to find on her own.

1219.text:
I am happy I have shot a few. Tried out the
new gun, tried out the new ear plugs. Had

1227.text:
a bit of fun and that is what it is all about.
This is one of the last ones we have shot.

1231.text:
It has got peas, a few greens in there, bit
of grass and it has got some rape in there

1240.text:
At the end of the afternoon Crow recovers
68 birds and as far as he can tell none are

1245.text:
missing in action - It's half the bag he'd
hoped for but to make him feel better Will

1249.text:
says it's the biggest bag he's ever seen.
Well done young'un - you will go far.

1256.text:
If you want to ask Andy anything about his

why not drop him a line at crow@fieldsportschannel.tv
He's a busy man so a quick response is not

Andy Crow there who even on a slow day makes

appearing up there on the screen above me.
Next it is, Hallo Charlie.

Hallo Charlie. Hallo Charlie. We are in Iceland

1290.text:
Hallo Charlie. It is Johnnie in Norfolk I
have been out shooting pigeons after the harvest

1295.text:
for the time. I have got between 80 and 90
pigeons. The only reason I have stopped is

1300.text:
because I have made a school boy error and

1303.text:
Hallo Charlie. My name is Danny I am just
on holiday in Greece with me deeks. As you

1308.text: can see enjoying the sun with me dogs.

Send us your own Hallo Charlie. Film yourself

Thank you for those. Please keep them coming.
Now, it's summertime, time to head for the

1331.text:
beach, and, once you have dropped your icecream
in the sand, you start to think about the

1340.text:
Sometimes when you are out in a boat on a
glorious summer's day, things just go right.

The English Channel is stuffed with mackerel
- and there's no better way my mum can think

1350.text:
of to entertain the grandchildren at the seaside
than to take them out handlining for these

1358.text:
Mackerel retail at about £5/lb in supermarkets.
Here's my mother into a fish that sells at

1365.text:
Here it is look at this. This is once in a

Hold on. Back into the net. Let it go backwards.

1397.text:
Once a year. Amazing this is a once a year
sort of a fish.

1407.text: A bass on a mackerel line. Extremely rare.

1410.text:
Fancy there just seemed to be a camera on
board.

1416.text:
Harry May is Lyme Regis harbour top salty
dog, running mackerel and other deeper sea

1420.text: fishing trips for more than 40 years.

1422.text:
I have done this year for over 40 years now
and I can't imagine doing anything else.

1426.text:
Lyme Regis is one of the top bucket-and-spade
seaside resorts in England. Located on the

1430.text:
south coast of Dorset, its harbour is surrounded
by a breakwater called the Cobb, made famous

1437.text: in the film 'The French Lieutenants's Woman'.

1439.text: I am going to let go.

1441.text:
Out at sea, the Jacoby children are getting
the hang of this mackerel thing. It's all

1444.text:
high reward stuff for the kids - and for the
grandmother.

1447.text:
A celebratory meal on granny at the Harbour
Inn.

1453.text: Yes. At the Harbour Inn Lyme Regis.

1464.text: Please, no, no, no. There is a bass in there.

1471.text:
You can have fish and chips later. But don't
show them that bass will you. We don't want

1474.text:
We are obviously doing well enough to attract

1479.text:
Back behind the Cobb, and we have sore hands
but smiling faces. Our two hours with Harry

cost £XX. We walk away with £20-worth of
mackerel by weight, and £30-worth of sea

1497.text:
Now only come on this next trip if you want

Now let's wind it out a little bit and look

1515.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show

Now there are lots of organisations involved

Back in the UK and with the Glorious Twelfth
around the corner, the Moorland Association

1547.text:
Another great summer activity that is good
for the environment and even tastes good is

1550.text:
hunting nasty American signal crayfish that

1554.text:
the UK ousting our own native crayfish from

and Picking Wild Garlic for the pot with ITV

Moving more firmly into fishing and viewer

In this one, made by the peak lobby group

Simon "Swamp Donkey" Penn is after barramundi

Now this is the time of year when you are
likely to find me and my family in a little

boat catching little fish off the English

with a noisy rock track, some massive steelheads
